spans.content: Sustainable zinc-air battery chemistry: advances, challenges and prospects
Qichen Wang, Shubham Kaushik, Xin Xiao* and Qiang Xu

Sustainable zinc-air batteries (ZABs) are considered promising energy storage devices owing to their inherent safety, high energy density, wide operating temperature window, environmental friendliness, etc., showing great prospect for future large-scale applications. Thus, tremendous efforts have been devoted to addressing the critical challenges associated with sustainable ZABs, aiming to significantly improve their energy efficiency and prolong their operation lifespan. The growing interest in sustainable ZABs requires in-depth research on oxygen electrocatalysts, electrolytes, and Zn anodes, which have not been systematically reviewed to date. In this review, the fundamentals of ZABs, oxygen electrocatalysts for air cathodes, physicochemical properties of ZAB electrolytes, and issues and strategies for the stabilization of Zn anodes are systematically summarized from the perspective of fundamental characteristics and design principles. Meanwhile, significant advances in the in situ/operando characterization of ZABs are highlighted to provide insights into the reaction mechanism and dynamic evolution of the electrolyte/electrode interface. Finally, several critical thoughts and perspectives are provided regarding the challenges and opportunities for sustainable ZABs. Therefore, this review provides a thorough understanding of the advanced sustainable ZAB chemistry, hoping that this timely and comprehensive review can shed light on the upcoming research horizons of this prosperous area.

Yadong Li and Prof. Yongpeng Lei. He is currently a Postdoctoral Fellow in Qiang Xu's group at the Southern University of Science and Technology. His current research focuses on energy electrocatalysis and rechargeable zinc-air batteries.

Shubham Kaushik received his BTech Degree in Chemical Engineering from the Indian Institute of Technology, Hyderabad, India (2016). Subsequently, he pursued his Master's and PhD degrees in Energy Science from Kyoto University under the supervision of Prof. Rika Hagiwara. After working at AIST-Kyoto University Chemical Energy Materials Open Innovation Laboratory (ChEM-OIL), he joined Prof. Qiang Xu lab as a Postdoctoral Researcher at the

Southern University of Science and Technology, China. His current research interests focus on the synthesis of single atom-based electrocatalysts for application in the oxygen evolution reaction. He is also interested in investigating electrolytes and electrode materials for rechargeable batteries.

The continuous increase in global temperature poses serious challenges to environmental safety. Especially, the depletion of traditional fossil energy and the environmental pollution problems make it urgent to take the path of green and sustainable development. Large-scale electrochemical energy storage devices with high energy densities and outstanding lifespans play a significant positive role in "carbon neutrality", demonstrating a bright future.

After decades of development, the energy density of Li-ion batteries has gradually approached the theoretical limit. In addition, the organic electrolytes used in Li-ion batteries have safety hazards, which have become prominent. Meanwhile, other electrochemical energy storage systems, such as fuel cells and metal-air batteries, have been developing rapidly and have begun to provide more options for various application scenarios.
Compared to organic electrolytes, aqueous electrolytes are generally more environment friendly and can effectively reduce safety problems.

Metal-air batteries (metal: Li, Na, K, Mg, Zn, Al, and Fe) with half-open configurations, utilizing oxygen in air as the active material, have been regarded as promising next-generation battery candidates owing to their high energy densities (Fig. 1a). Among them, Li-air batteries have the highest theoretical energy density of
, but the metallic Li anode exhibits poor stability in aqueous systems and air atmosphere. Meanwhile, Na/K anodes also suffer from unsatisfactory stability. Although
air batteries have a high energy density and excellent stability to water and air, their low reduction potential causes serious self-discharge phenomena and poor coulomb efficiency. Fe-air
batteries have a relatively low energy density of
. Zn-air batteries (ZABs) have received intensive research and development focus because of their high theoretical energy density

, abundant reserves of Zn metal, good rechargeability, low manufacturing cost, high safety, and eco-friendliness. Importantly, ZABs can be matched with other types of energy storage battery systems to achieve complementary advantages. In terms of the feasibility of commercialization, ZABs are considered to have the highest potential, attracting extensive attention from academia and industry. Over the past decade, the number of reports regarding zinc-air or Zn-air batteries began to rapidly increase (Fig. 1b).
ZABs have a history of nearly 150 years since their invention. The earliest ZAB was a primary battery using

aqueous solution as the electrolyte in 1868.[14] However, there were issues such as low working voltage and poor stability, which could not be solved. In 1932, Heiser and Schumacher changed the electrolyte from neutral to alkaline media, which improved the discharging performance of ZABs.[15] Meanwhile, the packaging technology of batteries has also been upgraded, allowing alkaline ZABs to serve as a power source for hearing aids, railway signals and other equipment. Furthermore, the working lifespan of primary ZABs can be extended by mechanically replacing the Zn electrode and electrolyte. In 2006, a gel electrolyte was reported for alkaline ZABs.[16] In the past twenty years, the substantial progress in nanotechnology has driven the development of materials and catalytic science, and thus the development of rechargeable ZABs.[17] However, achieving stable electrochemical charging is the biggest challenge for rechargeable ZABs. To date, the full potential of rechargeable ZABs has not been realized. The

He received the Thomson Reuters Research Front Award in 2012 and Humboldt Research Award in 2019 and was recognized a highly cited researcher (2014-2022) by Thomson Reuters/ Clarivate Analytics. He is a Fellow of the Engineering Academy of Japan (EAJ), European Academy of Sciences (EURASC), and National Academy of Sciences, India (NASI).

fundamental challenges are as follows: (i) high polarization and fast degradation of the air cathode, (ii) low interfacial compatibility and stability of the electrolyte, and (iii) poor electrochemical irreversibility of the Zn anode. Thus, the rational design of individual components and device systems is essential to achieve a satisfactory performance in sustainable ZABs. Currently, electrocatalytic oxygen reduction/evolution reaction (ORR/OER) catalysts for the air cathode have been intensively explored. With a deeper understanding of ZABs, the electrolyte, Zn anode and electrolyte|electrode interface stability also exert a great influence on the reaction mechanism, performance improvement, etc. In addition, maintaining the electrochemical interface stability is the key to ensuring the long-term stable operation of ZABs.
In recent years, many groups have summarized the development of ZABs, including oxygen electrocatalysts, electrolytes,

Nevertheless, special attention and deep discussion on sustainable ZAB chemistry have not been reported to date. In this review, we focus on the latest progress and challenges associated with sustainable ZAB chemistry (Fig. 2). To provide an in-depth understanding of ZABs, our discussion mainly focuses on the design principles of key materials and their structure-property relationship at the atomic level. From the perspective of reaction mechanism, we briefly summarize the significant advances of different types of ZABs. Secondly, the air cathodes are systematically introduced, including atomic-level engineering, oxygen electrocatalysts and the design of air cathodes. Then, the characteristics of ZAB electrolytes and the corresponding design principles are comprehensively reviewed. Subsequently, the problems faced by the Zn anode and the current strategies for its stabilization are

summarized. Meanwhile, the advances in the in situ/operando characterization of ZABs with respect to the relevant reaction mechanisms and electrolyte/electrode interfacial behaviours are also presented. Finally, we propose the current challenges and future opportunities that are expected to promote the development of sustainable ZABs.

In recent years, the deep integration of interdisciplinary studies has promoted the rapid development of sustainable ZABs, which is embodied in breakthroughs in oxygen electrocatalysts, electrolytes, Zn anodes and device design. These advancements not only lead to a deeper understanding of sustainable ZABs, but also broaden their application scenarios. In addition, the external environment also has a vital influence on the performance of ZABs, which requires careful attention and fine exploration. In this section, we aim to introduce the fundamental concepts of ZABs, and then classify ZABs according to their specific functions. Then, the characteristics and advantages of different types of ZABs will be emphasized. Finally, the integrated design of ZABs with other functional devices is also presented.
2.1 Basic principle of the ZAB configuration

In general, the charging-discharging performance and energy efficiency of ZABs are constrained by the sluggish

conversion kinetics of the cathode.[26] In the actual reaction process, a certain overpotential is required to overcome the thermodynamic and kinetic barriers. The oxygen electrocatalyst is of paramount importance to accelerate the ORR/OER process for sustainable ZABs (Fig. 3b). Taking alkaline media as an example, oxygen electrocatalysis should proceed through a four-electron process because the two-electron process would form
ions, thereby poisoning the active sites and reducing the catalytic activity and stability. The binding energy of the reaction intermediates

per elementary reaction cannot be independently controlled, leading to different rate-determining steps. The ORR and OER have distinct pathways, which require different active sites because of the difficulty in achieving an optimized oxygen binding strength. Different types of oxygen catalysts have different volcano curves. The closer the vertices of their respective volcano curves for the OER and ORR, the better their bifunctional activity.[27] Commercial Pt/C and Ru/Ir-based noble catalysts are widely accepted as ORR and OER catalysts, respectively. However, the low abundance of noble metals and their poor stability limit their large-scale applications. Therefore, the precise design and synthesis of inexpensive and efficient bifunctional oxygen catalysts as substitutes are of both scientific and practical significance.

2.1.2 ZAB evaluation parameters. In the field of sustainable ZAB chemistry, some important evaluation parameters are required to qualitatively assess the oxygen catalytic activity and ZAB performance. Here, we introduce some concepts or definitions of fundamental parameters for easier understanding.

value reflects better bifunctionality. Open-circuit voltage (OCV) for ZABs: the voltage difference between the cathode and anode when there is no current. Power density: the relationship between the current density and voltage when ZABs are discharged. Rate performance: discharging voltage platforms at different current densities. Specific capacity: the quantity of electricity that can be released by a unit mass of Zn anode, which is closely related to the oxygen catalyst. Energy density: the amount of energy stored in a certain space or active material. Cycle stability: the cycling behaviour of sustainable ZABs during the continuous charging-discharging process. Aqueous ZABs consist of a Zn anode, liquid electrolyte, and air cathode (Fig. 4a). The electrolyte also acts as a separator, preventing the short circuit of the battery. However, a separator is not necessary if the anode and cathode can be stably fixed. The distance between the anode and cathode affects the internal

resistance and redox reaction rate at the electrode|electrolyte interface.[29] Generally, the shorter the distance, the higher performance of ZABs. In the charging process of ZABs, a large number of bubbles cover the catalytic active sites of the air cathode, leading to the degradation of their cycling performance. As a semi-open system, the electrolyte stability is the key factor determining the charging-discharging ability and service lifespan of ZABs. Compared with the conventional static electrolyte, a flowing electrolyte significantly improves the electrochemical performance of ZABs by minimizing the unfavourable effects.[30-32] The flowing electrolyte reduces the concentration polarization, thus enabling favourable rechargeability and excellent stability even at a high current density. Nonetheless, aqueous ZABs are prone to leakage problems, bringing security risks. In this case, aqueous electrolytes were replaced with quasi-solid-state (QSS) gel polymer electrolytes (GPEs), resulting in flexible and stretchable ZABs, which possess a broad application prospect in wearable devices, robots, etc. The configuration of QSS ZABs includes sandwich type and cable type (Fig. 4b and c, respectively).[33,34] In the case of sandwich-type QSS ZABs, a GPE is sandwiched between the Zn anode and the air cathode. The sandwich-type structure is similar to aqueous ZABs, which is the more popular configuration. Moreover, sandwich-type QSS ZABs can deliver a stable voltage response under different bending or twisting conditions. In the case of cable-type QSS ZABs, they adopt a typical coil design. The Zn anode is located at the center, which is wrapped by GPEs. Then, the catalyst layer-loaded air electrode is winded on the ZABs. Moreover, QSS ZABs exhibit excellent capability to adapt to complex mechanical forces and deformations.[35] The matching of the mechanical strength of different materials should also be considered to ensure long-term stable operation. Considering the complexity of the working conditions, a suitable pressure is employed to maintain good interfacial contact.[36] Additionally, the output performance can be adjusted by series or parallel connection of the battery pack.[37,38]

The usage of aqueous electrolyte usually requires bulky, rigid structures and additional packaging materials, which makes structural design and size minimization difficult. Thus, to promote the practical application of ZABs, the development of pouch cells and coin-cells is necessary. 1-Ah-scale zinc-air pouch cells (ZPCs) were established via the simultaneous optimization of the cathodes, electrolytes, and anodes (Fig. 4d).39 The 1-Ah-scale ZPCs exhibited ultrahigh cell-level energy densities, long-cycle life, and wide operating temperature range. Coin-type ZABs have a small size and simple structure, which are convenient for batch assembly.40 The assembly process of coin-type batteries is relatively mature, and their structure is shown in Fig. 4e. To maximize the specific energy, the coin-type battery is filled with

powder to the maximum limit, and the metallic shell is directly used as the current collector. The numerous holes on the cover are designed for oxygen input. The coin-type ZAB is covered with sticky gypsum in the storage state to avoid electrolyte volatilization and prolong its shelf life. Schmidt and coworkers successfully developed a micro ZAB (size of

) on a chip through microimprint fabrication, which is compatible with the microelectronic manufacturing process (Fig. 4f).41 The ZAB on the chip showed excellent volumetric power density and volumetric energy density.

When electrochemical reactions are performed under extreme conditions, the reaction entropy is greatly affected by temperature. The output voltage is a key parameter reflecting the electrochemical reaction rate. Generally, the low-temperature polarization of ZABs includes three aspects, i.e., activation polarization, ohmic polarization and concentration polarization.
In the low-potential window just beyond the equilibrium potential, the electrochemical reaction is in the state where

molecules are activated, triggering the reaction to proceed. An overpotential is used to overcome the activation energy of the electrochemical reaction, causing activation polarization. At a low temperature, the ionic conductivity of the electrolyte decreases, and the electron transport between the electrodes and interfaces also decreases, resulting in a significant increase in ohmic polarization. At a high potential, the ionic diffusion rate of the electrolyte is slower than the electrochemical reaction rate due to the limitation of mass transfer, causing concentration polarization. Hence, low-temperature ZABs show a low critical current density and limited cycling stability. Zhang's group found that aqueous ZABs had intrinsic advantages in low-temperature energy storage (Fig. 5a).

On one hand, the oxygen redox kinetics were hardly affected by a change in temperature (Fig. 5b) based on the Arrhenius equation. On the other hand, the collinearity of the aqueous high-concentration alkaline electrolyte ensured a low freezing point, rendering effective ion diffusion.

However, the ionic conductivity of the electrolyte decreased significantly at subzero temperatures (Fig. 5c). The ohmic polarization was the main bottleneck for improving the low-temperature performance.

At high-temperature operation, the electrolyte retention ability and side hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) on the Zn anode are the limiting factors in attaining a robust operation in ZABs.44 High operation temperatures enable lower electrolyte viscosity and higher ionic conductivity, which facilitates mass transfer and reduced ohmic impedance. As shown in Fig. 5d, the

redox kinetic was significantly enhanced at high temperature. The passivation of the Zn anode was greatly restrained and the Zn dissolution kinetics also improved. The boiling point of the alkaline electrolyte
owing to the colligative properties of the solution. The achieved maximum power density
because of the fast reaction kinetics. The ZABs stably cycled at

, but realizing their long-term operation was still challenging. Meanwhile, the side HER kinetics of the Zn electrode was obviously enhanced, which decreased the charging efficiency. Conclusively, the unprecedented advantages of ZABs show excellent broad temperature-adaptability

with high performance under harsh working conditions. In addition, owing to their ionic hydration and H-bonds, GPEs with excellent antifreezing ability and thermal stability are promising candidate materials to broaden the working temperature range of ZABs.45,46 QSS ZABs can adapt to changes in temperature (Fig. 5e), which may be a research direction for temperature-adaptive ZABs.

ZABs only work in the presence of air, which greatly limits their application. Among the aqueous Zn-based batteries, the

Cu/Ni batteries have the characteristics of high voltage and large capacity.[55-57] Importantly, compared to ZABs, they are closed systems that can be used in a variety of environments, including anaerobic conditions. However, bifunctional ORR/ OER active sites are always present in the cathode of hybrid Zn batteries, accompanied by the pseudo-capacitance effect of transition metal ions, which can realize different reactions simultaneously. When the ZAB mode is destroyed, the Zn-ion battery can operate independently. Interestingly, the hybrid battery design combining ZABs and other Zn-based batteries significantly improves the energy efficiency and cycling lifespan

Acidic electrolytes are highly important to protect the air cathode from

poisoning. Zhang's group built a novel hybrid ZAB by decoupling an acidic air cathode and neutral Zn anode (Fig. 6g). A novel double hydrophobic-induced proton shuttle shielding and hydrophobic ionic conductive film was synthesized by introducing hydrophobic ionic liquids and graphene in the hydrophobic polymer matrix. The obtained membrane could selectively transport the hydrophobic bis(trifluoromethane)sulfonimide anions

and persistently avoided the proton shuttle. Based on this double hydrophobic proton shielding film, the two electrodes worked independently in their respective environments, completely preventing protons from transiting from the cathode to anode. Compared with that in an alkaline environment, the utilization ratio of the Zn anode in ambient air was higher
. The hybrid ZABs achieved an unprecedented OCV as high as
, which was higher than the theoretical voltage of

. In addition, the construction of an asymmetric electrolyte by decoupling the working environment of the acidic air cathode and alkaline Zn electrode can solve the problem of
poisoning. Compared with traditional ZABs, asymmetric electrolyte-based ZABs can deliver higher discharge voltage.
Bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts with high activity and robust stability are essential for practical ZAB applications. It is acknowledged that the oxygen electrocatalytic reaction

/solid(catalyst)/liquid(electrolyte) three-phase interface and its intrinsic activity is closely related to the unsaturated coordination sites on the surface of the solid catalyst. Thus, regulating the local electronic structure and surface/interface characteristics through atomic-level modulation engineering is particularly important for optimizing the adsorption/desorption behaviour of intermediates, lowering the reaction energy barrier and accelerating the ORR/OER kinetics.[63] Herein, atomic-level engineering strategies are systematically introduced to effectively tune the electronic structure of diverse oxygen electrocatalysts. Meanwhile, some typical examples are simultaneously highlighted to understand their structure-activity relationship at the atomic level. In addition, the micro/nano-architecture and surface wettability of air cathodes also play a crucial role in the ion transfer for high-rate ZABs. In this section, we mainly review the atomic-level modulation engineering strategies for electrocatalytic ORR/OER.

For electrochemical reactions, the conductivity, number and activity of the active sites of catalysts are important factors to realize excellent catalytic performance.[64] Theoretically, the reaction energy barrier is used to evaluate the intrinsic catalytic activity of materials. Six atomic-level engineering strategies, including morphology and nanopore control, defect engineering, doping modification, curvature control, heterostructure construction, and nanocomposite strategy, play a considerable role in tuning the electronic structure of solid materials. These atomic-level modulation engineering methods deepen the understanding of the performance improvement mechanism and provide essential guidance for constructing highly efficient bifunctional catalysts.

3.1.1 Morphology and nanopore control. Nanostructure design with an appropriate porous structure is conducive to exposing the active sites and accelerating the mass transfer during the electrochemical process. Especially, the hierarchical morphology shortens the molecule/ion diffusion length in the electrolyte and maximizes the mass/charge diffusion throughout the electrode, thus significantly enhancing the accessibility to the active sites.[65] The construction of hierarchical pore structures is attractive for the fabrication of high-rate ZABs that can work at high current densities. Compared to micropores and macropores, mesopores have more advantages in terms of mass transfer, gas transportation, and electrolyte infiltration. Mesopores with a size of

exhibit a good balance between resisting water permeation and ion diffusion capacity.[66] The nanoscale-grade separation strategy can solve the mass transfer problem by constructing ordered 3D interconnected sub-

mesopores.[67] The mesopore channels of 2D ordered mesoporous carbon (OMC) are at a long distance and bubbles can only diffuse outward along the axial direction through the mesoporous channels. 3D OMC with interconnected channels enables the generated bubbles to move freely along with fewer interruptions, leading to a higher transport efficiency. Therefore, a unique structure design is required to overcome the diffusion limitation.

3.1.2 Defect engineering. Careful control of the defects (e.g. type, concentration, and spatial distribution) at the surface/interface of solid catalysts to alter their catalytic behaviour is known as "defect engineering".[76,77] Defect engineering is a widely accepted method to tune the intrinsic electronic structure of materials. For example, surface defects can significantly tune the electron density near the Fermi level

and enhance the orbital hybridization, leading to the generation of more unsaturated coordination sites and dangling bonds. Generally, it is agreed that the catalytic activity at the edge is higher than that at the basal-plane. Defects include inherent defects and externally introduced defects. The rational design and development of bifunctional oxygen catalysts are significant challenges in this field. Combining various atomic-level modulation strategies, scientists have developed cheap electrocatalytic materials with high activity, high selectivity, and robust stability. These strategies contribute to the rational design and precise synthesis of catalysts. The reported oxygen electrocatalysts commonly used in sustainable ZABs are composed of diverse materials. The specific conditions will be discussed in the following section.
3.2.1 Noble-metal catalysts. Currently, the platinum group metals (PGMs) have been widely studied as oxygen electrocatalysts for application in ZABs owing to their optimal electronic structures.

Unfortunately, commercial carbon-supported PGM nanoparticles suffer from severe agglomeration or deformation during long-term operation, resulting in their deactivation and inferior stability. In this case, their encapsulation in carbon can effectively inhibit their detachment and agglomeration. Besides, improving the intrinsic catalytic activity of PGMs with high atom utilization is necessary to reduce the dosage of PGMs. For active PGMs, the ligand effect, strain effect, high-index facets, and synergistic effect can adjust their interaction with the reaction intermediates, which are regarded as the main reasons for their enhanced performance.
Considering this, numerous efficient PGM-based oxygen catalysts have been developed.

3.2.2 Nanocarbon and metal/carbon-based catalysts. Due to the numerous merits of high conductivity, adjustable porous structure, good chemical stability, and affordable price, carbon-based catalysts have been widely investigated in the field of energy electrochemistry.
However, the limited number of active sites and insufficient catalytic ability of the individual sites in carbon materials make their direct reaction with

molecules difficult. The tailored electronic structure and surface chemistry of carbon provide more possibilities for engineering advanced oxygen catalysts. Non-carbon atoms as dopants exist in the edges or planes of carbon materials. Especially, N doping results in different configurations (pyridinic-N, graphitic-N, and pyrrolic-N) (Fig. 10a). In addition, the armchair edges and zigzag edges are also electrochemically active, which can be further functionalized with heteroatoms to generate catalytic sites with higher intrinsic activity. In 2009, Dai's group proved for the first time that N-doped carbon nanotubes (CNTs) could catalyze the ORR in alkaline media.

The origin of their performance was strongly associated with their modified electronic structure. This important discovery promoted the vigorous development of metal-free carbon-based catalysts. To date, carbon catalysts

3.2.3 Transition metal compound catalysts. Transition metal compounds (TMCs) can be directly used as oxygen catalysts, but their performance still lags behind that of noble metal catalysts. The relatively poor surface/interfacial electron transport and limited catalytic ability are the factors restricting the efficiency of TMCs for oxygen electrocatalysis. It has been observed that the electronic structures of TMCs can be regulated by varying their anions, which is reflected in their ORR/OER performances. Generally, the catalytic activity of TMC electrocatalysts mainly originates from the unsaturated atomic coordination on their surface. Therefore, the atomic-level modulation of TMC-based oxygen electrocatalysts is required to modulate their electronic structure and enhance their interaction.

Hydroxides and LDHs are generally active for the OER, while relatively less active for the ORR.155,156 In this case, their poor ORR activity can be addressed by coupling functional carbon supports with good ORR activity.117 Meanwhile, the conductive carbon network constructs an electron pathway for hydroxides/ LDHs to significantly boost the OER. To further improve the oxygen catalytic activity, Han et al. demonstrated that Sincorporated NiFe-LDH on N-doped graphene (S-LDH/NG) acted as bifunctional oxygen electrocatalyst for rechargeable ZABs.157 The mismatch substitution of introduced S species led to a tailored topological microstructure and optimized electronic structure for boosting the activity and durability. Consequently, the as-fabricated ZABs with the S-LDH/NG cathode achieved a
. Yu et al. tuned the proportion and valence state of metal ions in Ni-Fe-Co oxide/hydroxide to significantly modify its electronic structure.

3.2.4 Atomically dispersed metal site catalysts. 3.2.5 Metal-organic frameworks and their derivatives. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) possess periodic metal atom-organic linker arrangements, large specific surface areas, tuneable pore structures, and other prominent features.[205,206] However, the low coordinative unsaturated metal sites (CUMSs) and poor conductivity of as-synthesized MOFs are the main reasons limiting their application in bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysis.[207,208] Recently, MOFs have emerged as a new platform for the synthesis of TMC/C hybrids and carbon-supported ADMSCs with improved catalytic performance through carbonization.[209-211] Particularly, the atomic-level uniform distribution of metal ions in MOFs can guarantee a satisfactory dispersion of TM species embedded in the carbon matrix. As subclasses of MOFs, zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs) and metal-triazolate frameworks are commonly reported.[212-214] Their organic linkers can be in situ converted into porous carbon materials through high-temperature pyrolysis. active sites. Due to the flexibility of their metals and organic linkers, MOF and MOF-derived catalytic materials with dense active sites have received significant attention.

Atomic-scale engineering strategies for the preparation of oxygen electrocatalysts can significantly improve their ORR/OER catalytic activities and greatly reduce the polarization problem of ZABs. However, tuning the surface/interface of the electrocatalyst alone cannot fully improve the delivered performance of ZABs. This is because the actual working environment of the air cathode in ZABs is completely different from the test environment during rotating disc electrode (RDE) measurement. In half-cell experiments, the RDE minimizes the diffusion transfer resistance and reduces the concentration polarization due to the forced convection at high rotating speeds, thereby maximizing the inherent catalytic activities. However, the operating environment of the air cathode in full ZABs is generally tested under static conditions, in which the reactant diffusion resistance is a critical factor in the mass transfer efficiency. Although a series of advanced ORR/OER electrocatalysts has been developed, the stable operating current density of ZABs usually does not exceed
. Therefore, it is of great significance to develop reasonable strategies to optimize the surface/interface structure of air cathodes for overcoming the performance bottleneck of ZABs.

3.3.1 Architecture design. Conventional air cathodes are prepared via the drop coating or spraying process, generating a limited 2D interface between the catalyst layer and gas diffusion layer (GDL).<sup>242</sup> However, due to the insufficient utilization of catalytic sites and unstable interface contact, they do display intrinsic activity, resulting in serious polarization. Thus, to construct an enlarged triple-phase reaction interface, an integrated air cathode was proposed. The architecture of the integrated air cathode possesses three main components, i.e., a catalyst layer,

To strengthen the mass transfer efficiency, the hydrophobicity and pore structure of the air cathode should be tuned, ensuring an adequate oxygen supply at the triple-phase interface.[243] The hydrophobic polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) is often used owing to its good hydrophobicity. In addition to the hydrophobic coating function, PTFE is also a binder, protecting and separating the components from the conductive skeleton. Thus, the appropriate introduction of PTFE is also an important prerequisite for achieving a good ZAB performance. One typical method is to mix the catalyst powder, porous carbon, and polymer binder and press the slurry onto a current collector. However, the low conductivity of the polymer binder will severely decrease the active surface area and cause undesirable boundaries, resulting in poor electron transfer and mass transport. Also, the polymer binder easily decomposes during repeated cycles. Hence, the design of integrated air cathodes without polymer binder is necessary.

It is helpful to construct orderly micro/nano structures to realize fast gas diffusion, aiming to improve the efficiency and working stability of oxygen electrocatalysis. The integrated nanoarray air cathode has great advantages in strengthening the triple-phase reaction interface.[244-246] The intimate connection and strong adhesion between the catalyst material and the conductive matrix ensure rapid electron transfer and long-term operation. The electrolyte is a vital component of ZABs, which determines the battery mechanism (4- or 2-electron oxygen redox chemistry) and the delivered performance. Nevertheless, relatively little attention has been paid to the electrolyte of ZABs. The commonly used electrolytes include aqueous and non-aqueous electrolytes. Currently, the commonly used electrolytes are highly concentrated alkaline solutions with soluble
salts. On the one hand, the strong alkaline environment has high reactivity with the metallic

anode. The key challenges associated with alkaline ZABs are closely related to the strong alkaline environment, resulting in poor cycling behaviour and low electrochemical reversibility owing to the instability of the electrolyte|electrode interface and the parasitic reactions, requiring the rational design of ZAB electrolytes.[255] On the other hand, aqueous electrolytes have good fluidity, but cannot meet the needs of flexible and stretchable ZABs. Replacing aqueous electrolytes with GPEs or anion exchange membranes (AEMs) can realize the mechanical flexibility of ZABs. In this section, we mainly focus on the recent achievements of ZAB electrolytes and provide an in-depth understanding behind their high performance, which is expected to advance practical implementations.
The electrolyte is a good ionic conductor and electronic insulator, playing a decisive role as a medium to transport

ions and oxygen species during the charging-discharging process. The physicochemical properties of electrolytes are closely associated with the solvation and transporting behaviours of cations/anions. In aqueous electrolyte,

ions. Furthermore, the pH dependence, electrolyte composition, cation effect, and halide effect should be considered when preparing electrolytes. Understanding these effects is beneficial to improve the performance of ZABs via rational electrolyte design. In general, an ideal ZAB electrolyte should have the following features: (i) high solubility and fast diffusion capability of
, (ii) wide electrochemical window, (iii) low volatility and flammability, (iv) stable electrolyte| electrode interface layer, and (v) good wettability.[256]

GPEs with desirable mechanical robustness, high ionic conductivity, and excellent compatibility with electrodes are critical for flexible ZABs.[288] Hydrogels are polymeric materials with 3D network structures, consisting of crosslinked polymer chains and inner aqueous electrolytes. The highly interconnected network of the polymer matrix provides enough space to lock the electrolyte and the unblocked pathways for ion diffusion. The crosslinking degree of hydrogels affects the mechanical strength and elasticity. However, the unavoidable evaporation of water causes the gradual dehydration of GPEs under ambient condition, leading to a sharp reduction in ionic conductivity and poor working lifespan.[289] Over the years, efforts have been made to develop a variety of GPEs for application in ZABs.

4.2.1 Fundamentals of gel polymers. In general, most synthetic processes include thermal-induced free radical polymerization or photo-excited free radical polymerization, which largely depends on the choice of initiator.[290] Many GPEs are synthesized via the polymerization of monomers to obtain polymer hosts, and then soaked in the corresponding aqueous electrolyte to get the targeted GPEs.[291] The amorphous phase in GPEs enables fast ion transport through the hydrated regions.[208] Here, some evaluation indexes are required to consider. Water uptake is the adsorption capacity of the polymer host for the aqueous electrolyte. The high water content of GPEs facilitates the ionic conduction and promotes the fast reaction kinetics. Ionic conductivity is a very important indicator, which strongly relies on the degree of hydration and ion-exchange capacities. Besides, when the polymer host is in the amorphous state, the segmental motions in the polymer chains increase the ion mobility. A high ionic conductivity ensures that the ion diffusion rate can catch up with the electrochemical reaction rate, which is an important prerequisite for achieving high-rate ZABs. To meet the temperature-adaptive requirements, the solid-liquid transition point and the glass transition temperature need to be measured. Flexible ZABs need to face complex mechanical forces and deformations. The excellent mechanical properties with both high stress and strain behaviour of GPE are essential. GPEs can be stretched over several times of their original length without breaking. The reliability of the contact between the electrolyte and electrodes puts forward higher requirements for the adhesion properties of GPEs. Their excellent adhesion behaviour enables them to be tightly bonded with the electrodes, thereby eliminating the need for fixation tools.

5.1.1 Corrosion. In Zn-based batteries, there are two main types of corrosion, i.e., self-corrosion and electrochemical corrosion. Owing to the higher negative redox potential of Zn metal than that of hydrogen, self-corrosion often occurs in alkaline media. Alkaline electrolyte has very high reaction activity for the Zn anode. The self-corrosion can also be regarded as the self-discharge phenomenon of the battery. The anode corrosion rate is highly linked with the pH of the electrolyte.[319] In weak acidic or neutral electrolyte systems, the self-corrosion phenomenon is less severe. The electrochemical corrosion mentioned here refers to the irreversible consumption of Zn metal in repeated charging/ discharging cycles, mainly including the Zn dropped from the anode into electrolyte and inert byproducts. Because these irreversible byproducts have low solubility and poor conductivity, they are easily saturated in the electrolyte and deposited on the surface of the Zn anode, reducing its active sites and reaction surface area, which is called passivation. As commonly observed, the cycling stability of ZABs is adversely affected by either self-corrosion or electrochemical corrosion. Thus, the corrosion of the Zn anode is unavoidable without protection. In this case, to retard corrosion, corrosion inhibitors (e.g., In, Bi, Pb, Sn,

5.1.2 Zn dendrite growth. Zn dendrite growth is a common issue in Zn-based batteries, which occurs in the Zn electrodeposition process. Especially, the formation of Zn dendrites in alkaline medium is more obvious than that in neutral or weakly acidic medium. The growth of Zn dendrites is closely related to the nucleation process of Zn, which is affected by the electric field, ion concentration, and surface energy distribution.[321] In the process of Zn nucleation,

ions undergo 2D diffusion along the surface. Zn will be preferentially deposited on the anode surface with priority nucleation sites, and then initial protrusions are gradually formed. The convex tip will produce a "tip effect", which further attracts

ions to deposit on the convex tip, accelerating the growth of dendrites. As the cycle proceeds, these convex tips will be accumulated and grow into the corresponding Zn dendrites. Therefore, the factors of dendrite formation mainly include the uneven electric field distribution of

ions on the anode surface and unrestricted 2D diffusion.[322] The plating/stripping efficiency is usually used to characterize the reversibility of Zn anodes. The "dead Zn" caused by Zn dendrite breakage also reduces the effective interface of Zn involved in the electrochemical reactions and the plating/stripping efficiency. The formation of Zn dendrites increases the risk of penetrating the quasi-solid gel electrolyte, thereby causing a short circuit in the battery.

Corrosion, Zn dendrite growth, and HER influence each other during the operation of ZABs. The formation of Zn dendrites increases the surface area of the anode and accelerates the HER rate. The HER increases the concentration of

, causing the formation of inert byproducts. The uneven current density of the bare Zn surface is beneficial for the HER, which in turn promotes the formation of dendrites. All these phenomena deteriorate the effective utilization and reversibility of the Zn anode. Usually, excessive Zn is used to maintain a long-cycle lifespan, but leads to a reduction in energy density and increase
in cost. These unfavourable effects cannot be completely avoided but can be alleviated by employing suitable stabilization strategies for Zn anodes.

6. Advances of in situ/operando characterization in ZABs

The multi-scale structural characterization of ZABs under realistic operation conditions is essential to design high-rate and long-lasting ZABs for practical application. Currently, the initial state and final state of oxygen catalysts can be studied by traditional characterization techniques, but the details of how ZABs gradually change from the initial state to the final state are not clear, which hinders the in-depth understanding of the battery mechanism. In this case, in situ/operando characterization techniques can provide insightful information on the structural changes, redox mechanisms, electrolyte/electrode interface evolution, failure mechanisms, and

-ion transport properties under the operating conditions (Fig. 26a).<sup>116,355-359</sup> In this section, the representative studies on in situ/operando techniques are summarized, and finally the major current challenges and future opportunities are discussed.

When the applied potential changes, the properties of oxygen electrocatalysts also change dynamically, thus converting the inactive materials under open circuit conditions into active electrocatalysts in the reaction process. Due to the complexity of the catalyst surface structure and the limitation of characterization technology in the electrolyte environment, it is still a significant challenge to accurately monitor the evolution of the active structure. ADMSCs have uniform catalytically active sites, providing an ideal model catalyst for the in situ characterization of the catalytic reaction mechanisms, especially for the symmetrical
site. The reconstruction from the initial
occurred in the ORR process.[360] This continuous structural evolution gradually adjusted the d-band center of the
site and balanced the free energy of the

intermediates, reducing the ORR overpotential due to the synergistic effect. In the case of asymmetric ADMSCs, the oxidation state of Fe species in the Fe-SAs/NPS-HC catalyst changed significantly in a potential-dependent manner under the applied potential from 1.0 to
[192] The oxidation state of atomically dispersed Fe sites gradually decreased. Chen and coworkers studied the real-time evolution of the local electronic structure of
sites from the ORR to OER via synchrotron radiation X-ray absorption spectroscopy.[361] It was found that the bond-length-extended
atomic sites acted as active centers during the ORR process (Fig. 26b), while the bond-length-shortened high-valence

By optimizing the intermediate adsorption, the synergistic effect between the atomically dispersed Mn sites and the N-doped carbon support improved the bifunctional performance. 6.2.1 Electrolyte|air cathode interface. The charging process of ZABs involves not only electrochemical reactions, but also the nucleation, growth, desorption, and transport of bubbles, and

other complex processes, which are closely related to the OER and carbon corrosion. The OER and carbon corrosion occur simultaneously and are related. Obviously, carbon corrosion lowers the charging efficiency and pollutes the electrolyte. However, the carbon corrosion of carbon-based bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts during the charging process is usually neglected. Amorphous and disordered carbons oxidize preferentially, which increases the ohmic resistance and decreases the charging kinetics. To monitor the released

in real time, differential electrochemical mass spectrometry (DEMS) was introduced to directly monitor the release of gas during different cycles. Tan et al. revealed the effects of three added conductive carbon materials (N/A, Vulcan XC-72 (VC), and CNT) on the cycling stability of ZABs.[367] Based on the in situ gas analysis, the type of carbon materials affects the release of
, while the charging-discharging voltage difference remained stable over 240 cycles. During the charging process, the

content was lower than that of the theoretical amount (Fig. 27b). The difference resulted from the carbon corrosion. At low current densities, the air electrode could maintain the "self-clean" state, which was an ideal state for charging. With an increase in the charging depth, the large bubble stage was obvious. More bubbles attached to air cathode led to additional charge transfer resistance. When the charging-discharging depth decreased again, the three typical stages disappeared, and only small bubbles were captured. Under a fast-charging condition, the generated bubbles became difficult to separate and tightly cover the electrode surface, which led to increased polarization. Tan's group built a detailed mathematical model with respect to the overpotential caused by
bubbles and pointed out the significant influence of bubbles on ZABs.[369]

An in situ optical visualization platform deepened the understanding of the dynamic evolution of the electrolyte|Zn interface (Fig. 27d).371 The interface stability was strongly correlated with the corrosion, dendrite growth, and HER. For example, a smooth interface of electrolyte|Zn was noticed when DMSO was added to the aqueous electrolyte, whereas severe Zn dendrites appeared in the DMSO-free electrolyte.103 A stable electrochemical interface enabled robust cycling stability even at high cycling rates. Cui and coworkers changed the viscosity to simulate the gel process of alkaline electrolyte and recorded the electrodeposition process of zincate ions on the planar Zn anode with different times (Fig. 27e).371 The growth process of Zn dendrites was visualized, together with a change in Zn deposition from uniform to uneven. The Zn electrodeposition process was divided into uniform and non-uniform regions. High current and high viscosity rendered the deposited Zn thinner and compact in the uniform region. This is because the high current provided enough driving force for deposition. The increase in viscosity hindered the ion transport, which made the distance effect more obvious. In addition to aqueous electrolytes, GPEs also showed considerable suppression of Zn dendrite growth, facilitating an excellent GPE|Zn interface by modulating the H-bond network. To clearly analyze the possible impact of the

group of PVA-TMG on the interface compatibility, Yan's group in situ monitored the interface behaviour between Zn foil and PVA-TMG.301 With an increase in the charging-discharging cycles, no protrusions or sediments were observed on the PVA-TMG|Zn interface. In comparison, protrusions and sediments gradually grew on the PVA|Zn

interface, accompanied with a dark layer. After 36 cycles, no Zn dendrites were generated on the PVA-TMG|Zn interface. In contrast, the accumulation of protrusions was noticed on the PVA|Zn interface. The in situ observations clearly suggested that the ionization of PVA led to the suppression of Zn dendrite growth.

Atomic-scale modulation of electrocatalysts, electrolyte engineering, and Zn anode interface modification can significantly promote the development of ZABs. In recent years, remarkable achievements have been reported in the fields of oxygen electrocatalysts, electrolytes, and Zn anodes, which have broadened the fundamental understanding of ZABs and bring more possibilities for their application. However, more in-depth and systematic works, both theoretically and experimentally, should be continuously carried out to tackle the tricky issues regarding ZABs. undoubtedly reduce the activation polarization. Especially for the charging process, a lower charging voltage reduces the structural damage of the electrode material, therefore improving the cycling stability. In the large overpotential region, the increased ion diffusion limitation is the bottleneck for high-rate ZABs, leading to concentration polarization. Tailoring the porosity of air cathodes is essential to achieve optimized charge transport and high-rate energy storage. Currently, most ZABs operate at low current densities below

. It is crucial to increase the current density, while maintaining the battery performance for realizing its practical application. In addition, although great advancements have been made, most electrocatalysts developed only work at low current densities and high charging voltages with a limited cycling lifespan of less than
. Hence, the development of bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts that afford low OER overpotentials at high current densities is crucial to achieve fast-charging ZABs.
(ii) Innovative ZAB electrolytes and novel reaction mechanisms
In the case of alkaline rechargeable ZABs, their
chemistry is well-defined. However, the introduction of functional additives may alter the

solvation sheath structure or H-bond structure of the alkaline electrolyte or the reaction pathway, giving unexpected properties to break their inherent bottleneck. Meanwhile, non-alkaline electrolytes not only avoid the limitations of alkaline electrolytes, but also ensure excellent electrochemical reversibility and cycling stability. The encouraging performance of non-alkaline ZABs indicates a new direction for the development of sustainable ZABs capable of long-term stable operation. Different electrolytes will lead to different intermediates and electron transfer pathways. Based on experimental results and characterization analysis, scientists infer the reaction mechanisms of electrolytes, and then combine MD simulations and quantum chemical calculations to deeply reveal novel reaction mechanisms. Innovative ZAB electrolytes and novel reaction mechanisms are highly desirable and remain a significant challenge.
(iii) In-depth understanding of the failure mechanisms of ZABs
To date, the deactivation mechanisms of electrode materials and the battery failure processes remain unknown, which limits

the rapid development of sustainable ZABs. It is well known that the smooth operation of ZABs is closely related to the interface stability of the air cathode|electrolyte|Zn anode. Based on combined in situ characterization (in situ XAFS, in situ XRD, in situ TEM, and in situ Raman) and finite element analysis (FEA) technology, it is possible to deeply explore the evolution of the electrolyte|electrode interface during the cycling process. Furthermore, researchers can study various the possible failure mechanisms of ZABs using these techniques. Compared to the air cathode, a rational design of Zn anodes with high utilization is an essential step toward practical electrochemical energy storage devices.
(iv) Temperature-adaptive ZAB systems and exploration of novel fundamental scientific phenomenon

The delivered performance of ZABs is affected by changes in temperature. However, the properties related to their low-temperature and high-temperature performances are rarely reported. At a low temperature, the reduced ionic conductivity of the electrolyte and the low critical current density are the main problems. At a high temperature, the parasitic HER and electrolyte evaporation have been identified as the main bottleneck, resulting in a low energy efficiency. To date, the research and knowledge on temperature-adaptive ZAB systems are still in their infancy and require urgent development, including performance breakthroughs and theoretical innovations. For example, the development of strategies to improve the transport kinetics of ions in the electrolyte and the diffusion in the electrodes at low temperatures is highly desirable but remains a significant challenge.
(v) Establishment of standardized test conditions and performance assessment standards

Most reported results on ZABs focus on oxygen electrocatalysts. Despite the obvious activity differences tested in the rotating disc electrode and rotating ring-disc electrode, they all claim that the performance of the as-synthesized catalysts exceeds that of precious metals (Pt/C or

) in ZABs. This is very puzzling. To promote the healthy development of this field, we propose the establishment of a standardized testing process (similar to Li-ion batteries). The key performance parameters (e.g., specific capacity, energy density, and cycling number) at high current densities should be encouraged, which have more reference values for practical application. In addition to oxygen electrocatalysts, the fundamental research on ZAB electrolytes and Zn anodes deserves increased attention.
(vi) From laboratory study to practical application

The prospect of sustainable ZABs in the future is very broad. To date, most manufactured ZABs are mainly in the stage of laboratory research and development, which still face great challenges from laboratory research to practical application. It should be noted that the synergistic effect of each component should be considered to achieve the optimal performances. Because ZABs are semi-open systems, their stable packaging should be considered. The inherent advantages of low-temperature ZABs cannot be
ignored, where polar inspections, high-altitude drones, aerospace and deep-sea explorations may be good application scenarios.
